_exec_summary.SummaryText:
PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Northridge Gas Plant maintains a policy of safe NGL treatment operations, reducing to the greatest extent possible hazards associated with the treatment processes, and reducing subsequent risk to the surrounding community, employees, and the environment.    

The Northridge Gas Plant has procedures in place, including both on-site activities and coordination with off-site responders that are to be followed in the event of a NGL release.

DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Northridge Gas Plant treats NGL in various aboveground vessels and associated piping and valves.  NGL is a flammable hydrocarbon mixture that may contain the following RMP-regulated flammables: propane, ethane, N-butane, isobutane, isopentane, N-pentane, and methane.  

The Facility also stores and processes the following RMP-regulated substances: methane and natural gas condensate.  Natural gas condensate is a flammable hydrocarbon mixture that contains isobutane, N-butane, neopentane (2,2-dimethylpropane), isopentane, and N-pentane.  Methane is stored at the Facility in its pure form.  

Although natural gas condensate is often classified as an NFPA Class 3 flammable substance, testing completed by EnLink demonstrates that the mixture would, at times, be considered an NFPA Class 4 flammable based upon the flash point and boiling point of the mixture. As such, EnLink has chosen to include natural gas condensate in the RMP-regulated inventory.

The following provides the maximum storage capacity and largest vessel capacity, calculated using100 percent vessel capacity, for all of the RMP-regulated flammables stored at the Northridge Gas Plant.

RMP STORAGE INVENTORY

Substance
Methane: Maximum inventory 3,700 pounds; Largest vessel 3,700 pounds
Natural Gas Liquids: Maximum inventory 1,104,826 pounds; Largest vessel 313,162 pounds 
Natural Gas Condensate: Maximum inventory 105,049 pounds; Largest vessel

ing emergency response equipment; 
Employee training; and 
Program review procedures. 

The Northridge Gas Plant maintains a written Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that provides guidance for emergencies expected at the Facility.  The ERP addresses all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  In addition, the Facility has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.

Operating procedures and equipment design codes and standards associated with the operations at the Facility are maintained.  Furthermore, the Facility has coordinated the ERP with the Hughes County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Calvin Fire Department.  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  The Facility has around-the-clock communications capability.  EnLink Gas Control and plant management are alerted in the event of a process upset.  The operator will then call the appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department).  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, EnLink conducts periodic emergency drills that involve emergency response organizations, and the Facility provides annua

l refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the facility.

SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS

EnLink has a continued commitment to update equipment and improve safety pertaining to the covered process when necessary.  The most recent Process Hazard Analysis for the Facility was completed on November 14, 2013.

The Northridge Gas Plant is a natural gas liquids (NGL) and gas dehydration facility (Facility), which utilizes more than the threshold quantity of a regulated flammable substance (10,000 pounds) in the processing of natural gas.  The NGL is an RMP-regulated flammable mixture.  Therefore, this Facility is subject to the Risk Management Plan (RMP) requirements codified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 (40 CFR 68) administered by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). 

The Northridge Gas Plant is also subject to Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and public receptors are located within the worst-case release scenario for the plant.  Therefore, the Northridge Gas Plant is subject to Program 3 requirements as stated in 40 CFR 68.10. OSHA's PSM standard closely parallels requirements outlined in USEPA's RMP Rule.  All elements required by USEPA's 40 CFR 68 - Program 3 Prevention Program are also required by OSHA's PSM. 

Within the last five (5) years, the Northridge Gas Plant has not had an accidental release of a regulated substance where exposure to the substance, its reaction products, overpressure generated by an explosion involving the substance, or radiant heat generated by a fire involving the substance led to any off-site death, injury, or response or restoration activities for an exposure of an environmental receptor.  

The Northridge Gas Plant employs 13 full-time employees on-site who ensure the proper operation and maintenance of the Facility.  

EnLink Midstream Operating, L.P. (EnLink), formerly Devon Energy Corporation, last submitted a full RMP the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) in December 2011 for the Northridge Gas Plant.  The current RMP includes administrative updates addressing the change from Devon Energy Corporation to EnLink and is being submitted as a full 5-year update.      

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE
